titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. General Pardo’s daughter dined with us, and went in the Evening with the Ladies to the play— The day was stormy, with frequent, heavy showers, and quite Cold— Mr: Harris says it is the breaking up of the Summer and that there will be no more warm weather— It can hardly be said there will be no more.— I wrote to Mr: Gray and part of a letter to my father— After my Evening’s walk, I read also, several Chapters in Smith’s Theory of Moral Sentiments— Nelson left us and enters the service of the Emperor.

2. Having neglected to walk this morning, I was confined to the house the whole day; the rain having set in from dinner time, and continued the whole Evening— Mr: Harris and Mr: W. S. Smith having broke down as they were going to dine, at Mr: Venning’s returned and dined with us— Mr: Glukoff came this morning and brought me a letter from Mr: Everett at Moscow— I read Massillon’s second Sermon upon a religious Profession— Its partition is upon the Temptations, and the Consolations of that Condition of Life— In the Evening I read Robinson’s Characters of Lot and Melchisedec— I can get very little from this Book; the design of which is much better than its execution— The ladies played and sung several Anthems.

3. The General of the Jesuits Brzozowsky paid me a visit this morning, and gave me a letter for the abbé Kohlmann, at New-York, which he desired me to forward with my letters— He said it was in answer to a request that he would send some fathers there; but the difficulties and the dangers of their passage at this time were so great that he could not comply with the request— I made some enquiries of him concerning the state of the Society here— He says they have a seminary for the education of fathers, between 6 and 700. Wersts from St: Petersburg—that they keep here a day school, where they have about two hundred boys, and a pensionary establishment where there are upwards of thirty— Among the latter is a Son of the Grand Marshal Count Tolstoy, and they expect soon to have another— They take no boys under seven, nor over twelve years of age— They teach Latin, French and Russian—with the usual classical studies—Rhetoric and Philosophy included— And the accomplishments of polite education— Dancing—drawing, and music— Their pension is at one thousand Roubles a year. Their Church is the first Catholic establishment in St: Petersburg— It consists principally of Poles; of whom there are about twelve thousand in the City— They have preaching every Sunday and Holiday, in four languages alternately—French—German—Polish and Italian— He asked me some questions about Bishop Carrol, who he said had lately been promoted to the rank of an Archbishop; but he did not know how many suffragan Bishops he would have under him— I went out with Mr: Harris, and dined at M. de Laval’s—in the Country— We arrived late, and found the Company already seated at table. There were about twenty persons—Gentlemen and Ladies— I had some conversation at dinner with Count St: Julien, and with Count Lüxbourg— Count St: Julien told me his Government had not protested against the annexation of Moldavia and Walachia to the Russian Empire— On returning home I left Mr: Harris, at Mr: Meyer’s. I received this morning a letter, and a number of New-York newspapers from Dr: Mitchill.

4. Visit this morning from Mr: Harris, and also from Mr: Fisher, with Captain Lovett; who proposes to go to-morrow, Evening to Cronstadt, and thence to sail for Boston— Mr: Harris informed me that he intended to pass the Winter at Paris, for which place he expected to go with Mr: J. S. Smith, in October or November— I dined at Baron Blome’s with a small Company— He was himself very unwell, and had apparently some fever— I walked home early in the Evening; and read some chapters of the Theory of Moral Sentiments.

5. Morning visit to Count John Potocki, who resides in the same house with us; he gave me several more copies of his new Publication upon the principles of Chronology, and also one or two previous dissertations upon the same subject— I sent him the only copy of my Lectures, which I have received, and also the second volume of the Memoirs of the American Academy, with a request for his opinion respecting the inscription upon the Dighton Rock— The Count shewed me the fac-simile of the celebrated Inscription upon a rock, lately found in Egypt, in Hieroglyphics, in the vulgar Egyptian, writing, and in Greek— He also lent me a work of Mr: Cordier de Launay, upon the beautiful, which he desired me to read— The Count, as
well as his brother Severin is about to retire to his Estates, and expects to leave the City next week— He is a man of great learning, and has paid particular attention to the antient classical languages— He thinks, and with some appearance of Reason that he has made important discoveries in the Science of Chronology, and that he has reconciled almost to a certainty the antient sacred with the profane Chronology— I found Mr: Harris with him— Mr: J. S. Smith dined with us. Catherine went into the Country to spend some days with Madame Colombi— Mrs: Adams went in the Evening to the Play— I finished reading the first, and began the second volume of Smith’s Theory of Moral Sentiments.

6. Morning visit from Mr: Harris and Mr: Richardson, the Gentleman whom on the day of our arrival here we met upon the quay of the Neva— He has since then been to Lisbon—to England—to Sweden—and perhaps elsewhere. Count John Potocki sent me back the volume of Memoirs of the American Academy, with a note assuring me that the inscription upon the Dighton rock is not Phenician— He hints that it possibly may be Norwegian— In my walk before dinner I met Baron d’Arnim, the Secretary of the Westphalian legation. He told me of a party they had made yesterday to Sisterbeck, to see a manufactory of small arms— I walked again this Evening; but met several interruptions in the course of the day, which prevented me from writing so much as for several days past.

7. Morning Visits from Dr: Griffiths, with Mr: Harris, and Mr: Montréal— Mr: Harris suggested to me a wish that I would speak to Baron Blome; respecting the American vessels which were lately taken into Norway; which I have already done— He also hinted the desire that I would obtain from Count Romanzoff, a written Note, promising that American vessels shall in future meet no more such difficulties and obstructions as they have lately met with— This however I do not think it prudent to ask, and if obtained might rather be useful to private speculation than of general service to the general commercial interest— As Mr: Harris intends to pass the Winter at Paris, I desired him before he goes to draw up a Memoir of such objects as he thinks might advantageously be included in a Treaty of Commerce— In case the Government should send me a full power to conclude one—which he promised; and said at the same time he would introduce to me, a Mr: Stieglitz, a very respectable and intelligent merchant, who could give me much information, and upon whose attachment to the interests of our Country, I could place entire reliance.— Besides these interruptions I wasted part of the morning upon trifles— On returning from my walk to the foundery this Evening I received a note from Baron Campenhausen informing me that the Emperor had ordered the vessels from Lisbon, concerning which I wrote to Archangel Count Romanzoff, to be admitted; and as the Post would not go untill Tuesday the 11th: by which the Official despatches could be transmitted to Archangel, if I preferred to forward them by express he would send them to me— The Season is so late that not a moment was to be lost— I wrote to Baron Campenhausen, by his own Messenger thanking him for his information, and accepting his offer to send me the papers— I immediately wrote a Note to Mr: Harris, desiring him to send the papers to Archangel by express; and promising to send them to him as soon as I should receive them— Between 11. and 12. at Night Baron Campenhausen’s Messenger returned, with a second note from him, and the dispatches— I wrote short letters to Mr: Rosilly and Captain Hopkins the persons who had applied for my assistance in this business, which, with the time for making copies brought it within a quarter of one in the morning before I was prepared. I then postponed sending the papers to Mr: Harris untill the morning.

8. Mr: Smith took the papers for Archangel, early this morning to Mr: Harris, who dispatched immediately the express— I had morning visits from Mr: Barthe and from Mr: Navarro, who was going into the Country— I went out to the French Ambassador’s Country house on the Peterhoff road, but did not find him at home— Walked back, and on my return stop’d at Count Bussche’s; but he was so unwell that he received no Company— The French Ambassador’s House is just at the fourth Werst-Stone— But the Stones are not placed at equal distances from each other— The Werst is 3500 English feet— My usual walk is 120 Paces to a minute; and a Werst is 1360 of my paces and takes me 11 minutes and 20 Seconds to walk.— An English Statute mile takes me 17. minutes, and 2050 of my paces. Although there can be no exact precision in this mode of measurement it is far more accurate than that of any mile-stones that I have ever found— And by this measure the distance between the
second and third Werst-Stones is about one hundred yards too great, and those between the first and second and the third and fourth, each about 50 yards too short— The Werst-Stones are pyramidical Stones erected on a Square pedestal about ten feet high. The first Stone is in the City, about half a Werst within the Gate— This is the point of departure, and there is a Sun–dial on the North and South-sides of the Pedestal— There is a similar set of Werst-Stones on the Moscow road. The distance to Czarsko Zelo and Moscow is Marked on these; as that to Peterhoff is on the others— After dinner I walked nearly to the Foundery, and in the Evening took a Russian vapour bath, at a bathing house near or on the Fontanka.

9. Visit this morning from Mr: Harris— I was not out excepting in the Evening for my usual Walk to the foundery; in the course of which I met Mr: Montréal— Catherine returned from her visit to Madame Colombi in the Country— I read the third Sermon of Massillon upon a religious profession— It is a dissertation upon the three vows of Chastity, Poverty and Obedience—duties which he says are contracted by Baptism; obligatory upon all Christians, and only strengthened with greater sanctity by the religious life— The Comparison with these obligations, their difficulties and their rewards as modified by the two different Conditions, is forcible and ingenious; the morality as good as it could be consistently with a recommendation of the monkish life— In the Evening I read Robinson’s Character of Isaac.

10. Mr: Raimbert called upon me this morning— I walked to the Shops and made a small purchase of books— Mr: Smith brought me several letters of heavy complaints from Archangel— Of Americans detained there— I dined at the French Ambassador’s, with a great company of about sixty Ministers, Generals and Senators— I mentioned to the Minister of Police, Balacheff, that I had already written to America, to have the black man’s wife sent out to him in the Spring; for which in the name of the Emperor he thanked me— He said the man had already entered upon his service, and waited upon the Emperor at table. The Grand Maréchal Count Tolstoy told me also that he had received my certificate in favour of Nelson, and had taken him into the Emperor’s service— But that he had refused to take him unless it was my wish— The Count has indeed been very polite; but Nelson says that he first sent for him to enquire whether he did not wish to serve the Emperor.— The Marquis de Traversey told me he was sorry that the arrangement for Mr: Jewett to enter the naval Service could not take place— That he would not take the Commission of a Lieutenant, and as Mr: Harris’s Certificate had only been that Mr: Jewett had commanded a Ship of 22 guns, the Emperor had remarked that it was only a Corvette, and not a frigate.— I spoke to Mr: Gourieff, the Minister of Finance; to whose department a great portion of the Affairs of Commerce have been transferr’d— I asked him if he had spent any time this Summer in the Country— He said no—that he was so much engaged in business that he had found it impossible to leave the City. I said that the Affairs of his Department must naturally engross all his time; particularly as I learnt there had been a great addition to them in the commercial business— He said that so far as commercial affairs related to the Finances, they were by the new arrangement placed under his direction— But the general management of commercial matters was entrusted to the Treasurer General of the Empire, Baron Campenhausen— I observed that as the Commercial Department was that upon which all the important concerns of my Countrymen depended, and as it was now under his Superintendence, I begged leave to recommend them to his protection and attention— That they were of great importance to my Country, and of course to me— And that I considered them of considerable consequence to the interests of this Empire, and especially to its finances— He said he so considered them himself, and that as far as depended personally upon him I might rely upon every thing that he could go to give facilities to our Commerce— I said that for some time past, great obstructions and difficulties had arisen to the admission of American vessels here, especially at the Port of Archangel; that I had presented a Note some time since to Count Romanzoff, relative to some of the cases, and had made verbal representations upon some others— Mr: Harris had also made various applications— That it gave me infinite pleasure that the Emperor, in every one of the cases had decided in our favour, and I was obliged to Baron Campenhausen for immediately communicating to me these decisions— But unhappily I found new complaints were still arising, as the old
ones were done away— That I had just seen several letters from Americans at Archangel, from which it would seem that their property had all been put under Seals, and that they were in the greatest alarm and consternation— Apprehending nothing less than a general confiscation— He smiled, and said that during the interval, or as it might be called, interregnum, while the business was transferring from one department to the other, some strange things had indeed occurr’d— But he hoped that now things would go on in better order— And besides said he, the Emperor Napoleon has given us a very good example, by his late transactions with regard to the United States—which I think we ought to follow— This was the key— And just then dinner was announced, and terminated our conversation. I sat at table between Baron Schladen, the Prussian Minister, and the French Consul, Mr: Lesseps, with both of whom I had much conversation— I told Baron Schladen, how sincerely I had been affected at the news of the Queen of Prussia’s death.— He expressed himself gratified at this notice of her, and said it was a consolation to find that she was not only generally lamented, but regretted even by those who had been her enemies while she lived— He afterwards asked me some questions about these new measures in France relating to America— I told him that they were opening their own doors, just at the same moment while they were shutting those of his Country against us— He said he hoped I considered that measure in its true light, as one which was assuredly not a result of the inclinations of his Government— I made him easy on that score by the fullest assurance, that I was fully satisfied whence it came, and harboured no resentment for it, against his Sovereign— He then told me that in consequence of the Conversation I had with him some months ago—v. p. 110. he had written to his Court, and mentioned that interview with me, adding a recommendation of the object, which I had appeared to wish— That he had received in regular time an answer to his despatch on that occasion, instructing him to come to a confidential explanation with me on the subject— That he was ordered to assure me that as far as the personal dispositions of the king and his Government went I might place the most perfect reliance upon it— And that every facility would be granted, which lay within their power— But then at the same time he said, he saw from the tenor of the remaining part of the dispatch, what sort of a turn affairs must take, and he had preferr’d to omit even the execution of his Instructions, rather than say things to me, which might have led me to form, and perhaps to communicate to my own Government expectations, which would be disappointed. The Baron’s intentions I believe were good, but I think I should not have been misled by his executing his instructions— Probably however he was not at liberty to explain the influence which was then pressing for our exclusion; and he could perhaps not have attempted to conceal it without a degree of dissimulation which a few days would expose, and at which he was reluctant— Mr: Lesseps’s conversation would not figure well upon paper— I asked the Grand Master of Ceremonies Narishkin, and Monsr: de Maisonneuve whether there would be a Court held to-morrow, as I had heard— They told me there would not, but that it was customary for foreign Ministers to attend at the ceremony of the Mass which is performed at the Monastery of St: Alexander Nevsky, at 11. O’Clock in the Morning; that places were given them; and that last year almost all the Ministers attended.— We dined by candle-light; for the first time this Season— In the Evening, after my return home, I received by an estafette, a couple of letters from Americans at Riga, who ask for my assistance to obtain admission for their vessels.

11. It is the anniversary festival of St: Alexander Nevsky, a Prince of Novgorod who reigned about the year 1250— And is also what they call the name day of the Emperor— At 11. O’Clock I went with Mr: W. Smith to the Monastery, where the crowd was great, and the concourse of the People from the Perspective to the Church, on both sides of the Street was excessive— When we got to the Church we found it difficult to ascertain a proper place to stand in— None of the other foreign Ministers was there excepting Count Schenk, who came in sometime after me, and who was as much embarrassed as myself— He took a place among the Officers in attendance on the Imperial family, which he found was not the proper one, and returned to where I had taken mine— Count Romanzoff, at length seeing me came to me, stood next to me during the whole Ceremony and explained to me many parts of the performances. The silver Shrine of the Saint is at the right hand of the Chancel, as you go up the broad aisle to the altar.— Before this Shrine was spread a large carpet, on which the Emperor took his stand; with the Empress at his left hand— Next to her the Empress Mother, then the Grand Dukes Nicholas and Michael, and the Grand Duchess Ann behind her mother— The Crown Officers and attendants were ranged in a line beyond
the Emperor, up to the steps to the shrine of the Saint— Prince George of Oldenburg, husband of the Grand Duchess Catherine, the Prince of Wurtemberg, brother of the Empress Mother, and a number of Officers, and Strangers stood before the Chancel on the right side of the aisle, and a number of ladies, and crowd of women at the left— The ceremony was performed by the Archbishop, and the other Priests who usually perform at the Imperial chapel, with the same quire of singers— But it was not a Te Deum; and differed in many respects from an ordinary Mass— Count Romanzoff told me that the two candlesticks, which the Archbishop occasionally takes in his hands; one with three lighted candles and the other with two, and which he waves downward crosswise, were symbolical of the Trinity, and of the double nature of Christ— Coxe I think mentions this— At a particular part of the Ceremony a sort of embroidered cloth was waved, or rather shaken over the Altar— The Count said it was during the Credo, and to express the uncertainty of the time, when the mystery of the descent of the holy Ghost commences— The Greek Church not having thought the precise moment ascertainable— After the Mass was finished, the Emperor went up to the Shrine of the Saint—knelt and kiss’d the silver coffin three times; twice at the side, and once on the top— The Empresses—Grand Dukes, and Grand-Duchess, all followed in turn, and repeated the same Adoration of the Saint— The Grand-Duchess Ann a beautiful princess of about 17 years of age performed her part at once, with the most complete prostration, the most grace and the most dignity— As the Empress-Mother descended the steps, the Emperor lent her his arm to assist her— There were then three small pictures in frames given to the Emperor and two Empresses, and small round loaves of bread to each of the members of the Imperial Family— On going out of the Church the crowd was so great that the passage out to my Carriage by the way at which we had entered was totally barr’d; I followed the crowd of the imperial Officers, through the only passage way that was open, supposing it led to another issue; untill I found myself unexpectedly in the Archbishop’s Apartments where the Emperor and his suite had been invited to a Breakfast— One of the Messengers of the Grand Master of the Ceremonies, gave me notice that the attendance of Strangers there was not usual, and I at length found the way out to my Carriage— The crowd of People in the Streets, continued as great on our return, as when we went— It was about 3 O’Clock when we got home— In the Evening I went with the Ladies, and for the first time took Charles with us to the German Play— It was an Opera, by Kotzebue—“Fanchon des Leyermäydchen.”— The Music by Himmel—on the whole, indifferent, though it has two or three agreeable songs.— Charles was much astonished and delighted— After the Play I walked as far as the marble Palace on the Quay— The French Ambassador’s House, was illuminated— Count Romanzoff’s Hotel and a number of other public buildings, also— At the Houses of all the foreign Ministers, and many others there was a shew of illumination; that is from a dozen to a hundred lamps with oil burning in front of each house, and sometimes half a dozen candles in the windows— I asked Count Romanzoff, at the Church, when he could see me again; and he appointed me Friday Morning at 11. O’Clock.

12. Long morning visits from Mr: Montréal and from Mr: Harris. While he was here, the French Ambassador also paid me a visit— I had been very desirous of some conversation with him, upon public affairs, but was now obliged a second time to postpone it. Mr: Montréal told me many circumstances respecting the capture of the Duke d’Enghien, which was done by a French Corps of troops under the command of M. de Caulaincourt— He was then Aid de Camp General of the First-Consul Bonaparte— He was of a noble family of Picardy, and his father had owed his fortune to the protection and patronage of the Prince de Condé.— He received an order to go to Strasburg—there to assemble the Commander of the troops, stationed at that place, the Mayor of the City, and two or three other officers—and in their presence to open a second sealed order which was delivered to him— On the performance of this duty he found it contained an order to take a column of troops which were placed at his disposal, to cross the Rhine, and enter upon the territory of the Grand Duke of Baden; to seize the person of the Duke d’Enghien who resided there in the Country at a house of his own, and transport him to the prison of Vincennes, near Paris— He was very much distress’d at having such a Commission entrusted to him, but he executed it; and it was for that service that he was rewarded with his Duchy, his Embassy here, and other rewards and honours. The Duke d’Enghien was residing at that place with the knowledge and consent of Bonaparte— He used even occasionally to go to Strasburg to the
Play, with the consent of Bonaparte, who had been asked whether he had any objection to it, and had made none— The Duke had notice of the approach of the French troops, and was advised to make his escape, as it was supposed they could have no other object than to take him; but he had refused, on the idea that it was impossible there could be any design to seize him.— He was carried to the Prison of Vincennes, and without any formality of process shot, at two O’Clock the next morning. The examination and interrogatories which were published the next morning in the Moniteur were sheer fabrications— No trial, and no interrogatory was had; and the persons whose names were signed to those seeming judicial documents never saw them untill they found them in the newspapers— The Duke was shot at two O’Clock in the morning, and buried in a ditch that surrounds the prison— There was another mysterious transaction of which the remembrance had been just renewed at Paris— About three years ago a Monsieur de Ségur, son of him who is now Grand Master of the ceremonies, and who was sub-prefect of Soissons suddenly disappeared, and nobody knew what had become of him— A few days before he had said in a company where M. de Caulincourt was speaking of his having been present at the passage of several rivers “but Sir, you say nothing about the passage of the Rhine[”]— It was rumoured that as a quarrel had ensued and violent words passed upon this speech Segur had been challenged, and assassinated in the Bois de Boulogne— But now, all of a sudden immediately after the disgrace of Fouché the Minister of Police, young Ségur has appeared again safe and unhurt— The conjecture is that Fouché had him seized and confined in some prison, and that by the change of parties at Paris he has obtained his liberation. Mr: Montréal promised me a copy of the official Notes between the French and Russian Governments on this affair of the Duke d’Enghien, and observed what a refinement of assumption it was to send Caulincourt here as Ambassador, after what had taken place— As Montréal went out, Mr: Harris came in, and was a few minutes after followed by the French Ambassador, with whom I wished to have some conversation, and could but partly accomplish my object— I dined with a Company of about sixty persons at Count Romanzoff’s—principally the same Company, and on the same occasion as the dinner of the 10th: at the French Ambassador’s— That is the Emperor’s birth name-day.— The Chevalier Navarro introduced me to Baron Campenhausen, the Treasurer-General of the Empire, whom I had not known before— I spoke to him of the vessels and cargoes of Americans in difficulty at Archangel— He professed to be very much concerned at these occurrences, and reprobated in the severest terms the conduct of the Commission for neutral Navigation there; which he told me he would entirely organize over anew— But these new organizations produce many more difficulties than they remove.— I also spoke to him respecting the vessels which have arrived at Riga, about which he desired me to write to him, so that he might state the case for the consideration of the Emperor. I spoke upon all these subjects also to Monsieur de Gourieff next to whom I sat at table— And I asked the French Ambassador, to have some further conversation with him, owing to the interruption which prevented me from having it so freely as I had wished this morning.— He asked me to come and dine with him on the Peterhoff road to-morrow— I also told Baron Blome the Danish Minister that I wished to converse with him concerning the captures of the American vessels lately carried into Norway— He told me he would call upon me to-morrow or on Saturday— Mr: Lohman sent me some English Papers, and a note saying he would call on me to-morrow. I called in the Evening at Mr: Harris’s lodgings, but did not find him at home— Walk on the Quay— The Ladies went to the play.

13. Mr: Lohman called according to his engagement— He has arrived here from England, by the way of Sweden, and came through Gothenburg the 18th: of August— He goes to-morrow for Riga—returns shortly here and in November expects to go back to England. Baron Blome also paid me a visit; and I urged to him the case of the American vessels taken into Norway; eight of which I knew to be Americans, which had sailed from Cronstadt, laden with Cargoes, all of property unquestionably American— I dwelt upon all the arguments which occurr’d to me, to shew the claim which they had upon the Danish Government to be discharged— He professed very good personal dispositions of his own, and asked me to write him a note on the subject; which he promised to transmit to his Government— About four O’Clock I went out to the French Ambassador’s Country-House on the Peterhoff road, and dined with him— There were only his own family, Mr: Lesseps, and three or four Russian Officers there— Before dinner I express’d to him
my surprize at the measures of France, towards the United States— The repeal of the Decrees of Berlin and Milan, removed the most important causes of our complaints, excepting the late seizures and sequestrations, which I understood were reserved for further negotiation— But at the same time here were orders to exclude us from the Ports of Prussia, of Holstein, and Mecklenburg—and other indications which seemed altogether incompatible, with the spirit of conciliation manifested by the other measure— He said the only way he could account for them was that they had been of prior date— But he said these were subjects upon which his Government said nothing to him— The only time they had spoken to him of our affairs, was, on what he had mentioned to me relative to General Armstrong, and on which he had requested me to write to my Government— I told him that I should certainly write to my Government, whatever I could think would have a tendency to reconcile the interests and policy of our two Countries— That he would be sensible that my situation in relation to General Armstrong, rendered me the last person, who in delicacy or propriety ought to be the medium of indefinite complaints against him to his own Government; but that if owing to any inconveniences of Communication arising from the state of things there, his Government thought proper to make any informal and inofficial observations, which they were desirous of transmitting to the United States, and would commit them to him, and he to me, I should take great pleasure in giving every aid in my power to every purpose calculated to restore harmony and good-understanding between the parties— A circumstance which might perhaps occur if General Armstrong should leave France, as I had heard was still his intention— I told him the French Government appeared to me still too much addicted to that repulsive policy, which the Prince of Benevento had justly assigned as the Cause; which under the former Monarchy, had occasioned the loss of almost all the influence in the United States that France had acquired during the War of the American Revolution— That the influence of France might be great if she pleased, but that as England by her conduct seemed determined to reconcile us with France, so France by her’s was rendering the same service to England— He told me that he would write the substance of my observations to his Government— That as to the complaint against General Armstrong; he did not understand it to be a thing which would injure his credit at home— But it was only said that he scarcely ever saw the Minister— That he never went to Court, and that whenever any thing was to be done, he was presenting testy Notes, which made written answers of the same sort indispensable, and which widened matters, when by verbal explanations they might be conciliated— So I now see the whole front of Armstrong’s Offence, is omitting to go to Court, and presenting Notes too full of truth and energy for the taste of the Emperor Napoleon— I had already mentioned to the Ambassador yesterday and repeated to him this day the Articles in the French Official Gazettes containing misrepresentations in matters of fact which produced injurious effects even here, to our Commerce—instancing particularly that the French Consuls in America had ceased to deliver Certificates of Origin— After dinner I walked home—and found letters from my friends at Quincy to the 12th: of July, brought by Mr: Jones of Boston.

14. Mr: T. M. Jones called upon me this morning— He sailed from Boston the 15th: of July; arrived at Gothenburg the 20th: of August— Came on immediately by land to Stockholm, and thence in an American vessel to Cronstadt, in three days— He is thus only sixty days from America— He purposes to spend the Winter here, and at Moscow— Mr: Donovan called on me, just as I was going to see Count Romanzoff, and at my request, again afterwards— He came for a Passport and is going first to Sweden, and then to England, or America— I went according to appointment, at 11. O’Clock to Count Romanzoff’s, and had some further Conversation with him— I told him that although the decision of the Emperor, upon all the cases concerning which Mr: Harris or myself had made representations was favourable, that I was continually receiving new, and more heavy complaints— That since the arrival of the revisor, who had been sent to adjust all the difficulties, they had been multiplied four-fold; and that in some instances there were now complaints of personal ill-treatment— The Count said he hoped that henceforth there would be no more occasion for any complaints, and read me a letter, which he had this morning received from Baron Campenhausen, in answer to what he had written to him, immediately after my last conference with him— This letter contained in substance the same thing which Baron Campenhausen had assured me of, in his
verbal message to me— That he had given the most precise and positive orders to the Commission of neutral Navigation at Archangel to expedite as soon as possible the business of the American vessels— That he regretted exceedingly the delays which had been occasioned by the neglect or misconduct of the Commission, and that he had thought it his duty severely to reprimand them for it. I then mentioned to the Count the case of the vessels which have arrived at Riga, after finding themselves excluded from the Ports of Prussia, and of Holstein; and which not having been originally destined to Russian Ports did not possess Certificates from the Russian Consuls, as in ordinary cases was required— He desired me to write him a note on this subject, which he would immediately recommend to the Minister of Commerce— He asked me whether I had heard a Report that the British fleet intended an attack upon Carlscrona, to take away the Swedish fleet that is there— I had; but I did not believe it— He said the king of England, had never acknowledged the present king of Sweden, and now that a French General was called as the successor to the throne, they would probably be still more exasperated in England against Sweden— I told him I understood that Carlscrona was too strongly fortified to be exposed to such an attack— The Danes he said were also apprehensive of an attack on Christiansand, and had lost some gun’boats at Bergen in Norway— I said it was impossible to feel much for them; they were inflicting all the injury they could upon our trade, and were obstructing particularly the trade with this Country—that of the 47 vessels they had lately taken into Christiansand, seventeen or eighteen were Americans; eight of them had sailed loaded from Cronstadt, and knew them to be of perfectly neutral property— The Count said that they treated them exactly in the same manner— And the only way in which he could account for it was to attribute it to want— They were so poor, and had now so scanty means of subsistance that they could not subsist without plunder— He asked me, what I thought would be the result of the late measures in France— I answered that as they were conditional, to depend upon corresponding measures on the part of England, it was yet very doubtful to me, what the result would be. Although England had repeatedly promised to revoke her orders in Council if France would repeal these decrees, yet as the whole advantage of the system on both sides had accrued to her, I was apprehensive she would not keep her word— She would cling as long as possible to the continuance of the system— He asked me whether General Armstrong was still at Paris; I said he was— He observed that while he himself was at Paris, General Armstrong once appeared at Court; which was much remarked, as it was said he was not in the habit of attending there at-all— That the Emperor then spoke to him— This was the Court of which the General gave an Account in his despatch, which I remember to have read while I was in the Senate of the United States— On leaving the Count I went to Mr: Harris’s lodgings, where I found with him a Mr: Andrews of Salem, just arrived from Archangel, deputed by a number of Americans there, and loaded with a fresh burden of complaints— He left Archangel the third of this Month— I supposed the first orders dispatched by Baron Campenhausen.— Mr: Harris agreed to send a new Note to the Baron, upon the particular business of Mr: Andrews— Mr: Montréal called on me, and left me a copy of the diplomatic Notes between France and Russia, which passed in the year 1804— Remainder of the day chiefly employed in reading English Newspapers.

15. Sent the English newspapers with a note to the French Ambassador— He had sent me yesterday the Moniteur, from 15. July to 15 August— Visit from Mr: Plumer, with Captain Lovett of the Hope, who sails for Boston in a Week or ten days— Wrote a note to Count Romanzoff, and one to Baron Campenhausen, to the last of which I received the answer, and sent a reply this Evening. Mr: J. S. Smith came at 4. O’Clock, and we went together and dined with Count Romanzoff— He had a small party of fourteen— Prince Yussupoff, and his son, Mr: Boucher, Mr: Harris and Mr: Barthe, Mr: Schulipoff, a Mr: Herman director of the Mines in Siberia, were of the Company— I walked in the Evening as usual, and the Ladies went to the Play.

16. Letter to Baron Blome, respecting the American vessels lately taken into Norway. Day at home, excepting a walk after dinner to the foundery— Weather so cold that we had fires lighted in one of the Stoves— Evening visit from Count Lüxbourg. I read the fourth Sermon of Massillon, upon a religious profession—the last in the volume— The perversion of moral Sentiment, which elevates the virtues of a Cloister above the virtues of an active life is conspicuous in this Discourse as in all the others on similar subjects.— It is noticed by Smith in his Theory, where he quotes a passage from the Bishop’s benediction of the Catinat
regiments standards— It is there merely an occasional and incidental remark; but it forms entirely the basis of these sermons on religious professions— In the Evening I read Robinson’s character of Jacob.

17. I had this morning another application from the Captain of an American vessel arrived at Riga, from Lisbon, for assistance to obtain the admission of his vessel— It was sent me from the brothers Severin as coming from Mr: Rodde the consular agent at Riga— I called upon Mr: Harris in the course of the morning, but did not find him at his lodgings— I wrote answers to two letters last week received from Riga, and began one to my Mother— Mr: J. S. Smith dined with us— In my Evening walk I met Mr: Jones, who was coming on a visit to us— I found him on my return home— Mr: Donovan also called upon me this morning for his Passport; and had some conversation with me respecting his Affairs— He is irritated against both the Houses of Cramer brothers, and of Meyer and Brüxner, and also against Mr: Harris— All of whom he thinks have used him ill— He told me that he should send me copy of a protest which he has made here, and also of some other papers, which would give me a clear understanding of his wrongs.

18. I called this morning upon Mr: Harris and Mr: Meyer, and returned the visits of Mr: Lewis, Mr: Tilden & Mr: Jones— On returning home I employed the remainder of the day in writing— The Ladies went in the Evening to the play— Mr: Harris pass’d it principally with me— He told me that Mr: Borel had called upon him this day, and assured him that the next year Commerce would be liberated from most of its vexatious shackles— Mr: Montréal called upon me this morning, and told me that Captain Cox would go this Evening, or to-morrow morning.— I find myself much hurried in business— I received this day from Mr: Donovan, the papers which he had promised me yesterday.

19. I wrote this morning to Baron Campenhausen, on the case of the Columbia, Captain Sullivan, at Riga; and to Captain Sullivan himself— Called on Mr: Meyer— Mr: Raimbert and Mr: Glukoff—left a letter for the Bankers at Amsterdam, at Mr: Meyer’s—the Packets to go to America, at Mr: Raimbert’s; and asked Mr: Glukoff for his account. Walk afterwards to the shops— Soon after my return home, Mr: Donovan called upon me, and had a long conversation with me concerning his affairs. He has very heavy complaints against the house of Cramer brothers, and some not altogether slight against Mr: Harris— He also complains of the House of Meyer and Brüxner; but that is only for making too heavy charges against him in his accounts—and refusing to settle with him by arbitration. He says that Harris sets up the advantages which he derives from his Consular Office here for sale; to the highest bidder— First to the House of Blando which failed—next to that of the Cramer’s, and now to that of Meyer and Brüxner— That he makes the Consular Agents whom he appoints in the out-ports pay him a part of their Commissions on consignments made to them, and has quarreled with Küsel, his Agent at Archangel, for accounting with the Cramer’s for this business, and not immediately with him.— He thinks it, and with some reason a defect in our Consular system, that the Consul’s having no pay are obliged to resort to such expedients— But he is so much exasperated that there appears to be some exaggeration in his representations— He said that in 1808 and 1809. it was customary for American Masters of vessels arriving here to pay from three to twenty-four thousand Roubles to Harris to be divided between himself and Count Romanzoff’s Secretary; to obtain admission— That twelve thousand Roubles was the sum demanded of him, but that he finally got it reduced down to three thousand, which he actually paid— When I asked him whether he was certain the money was divided between the Consul and the Count’s Secretary, he said it was a thing which he could not prove. That the Consular Office, at that time was the Counting House of the Cramer’s— That he paid the three thousand Roubles, for which in the first instance twelve thousand were demanded of him— That it was understood to be for the Consul and the Count’s Secretary, and that to his knowledge twenty-four thousand Roubles were paid by the Captain of one American vessel— None then obtained admission without paying, and the sum was always as large, as the Master could be perswaded to give— He mentioned a number of other abuses, and read me a letter which he had written upon the subject; of which I asked him and he promised me a copy— Messrs: Harris, Jewett, J. S. Smith, Barthe, Fisher, Jones, Lewis, and Tilden dined, and spent the Evening with us.

20. Captain John Seaman of New-York, came this morning, with a letter from Mr: Harris and asked for a Passport, which I gave him; he is about returning to America— The remainder of the morning I was undisturbed and wrote to the Secy: of State— Mr: Smith dined out of town— I went to the shops, but found many of them shut— This being a Holiday— The festival of the virgin Mary’s birth. I walked immediately after dinner— Mr: Andrews and Mr: Plumer were here part of the Evening.

21. I went this morning with the Ladies and Mr: Harris to the Academy of Arts, which is now open, and where there is an exhibition of Pictures. There is a very great collection of copies in plaister, from the famous Antique Statues— But most of them indifferently executed— The equestrian Statue of Balbus—and those of Marius in the curule chair, and Agrippina, also seated in a chair appeared to me the best— The knife-whetter is far inferior to that in Count Stroganoff’s garden— The pictures in the collection are of various merit; an are those in the exhibition— The Portraits of Prince Bagration, of Count de Maistre, and of Count John Potocki are very good— Some Landscapes, Sea Pieces, and Historical subjects are good— Many very indifferent. There is a model of St: Peter’s church at Rome, which takes one large room— The model of the machinery by which the Rock of Peter’s Statue was brought to the City, is also kept here— The Portraits of all the Directors of the Academy are bad Pictures and no likenesses— We saw drawings in black pencil dated 29. June 1796—by Alexander, then Grand-Duke, and now Emperor; and by his Sister’s Mary and Helen— They were heads, copied from the common studies of Scholars— There was one also done by the Emperor Paul— There was a great collection of Prints, generally very bad; and many models of buildings and antient ruins, in Corkwood— Among the rest was the model of the new Church of our Lady of Kazan in this City, one of the most magnificent Churches in the world— And the model shewed the manner, in which the arch between the body of the Church and the Colonade is supported— By a stone hewed in conical form, inverted. Mr: Thomond a French man employed as sub-director accompanied us part of the time, and Mr: de Torey, also a french man in the Russian Service, during the remainder— The Building itself is the most remarkable Curiosity— It forms a hollow square, each side of which isfeet the internal Court is a small rotundo— The Architecture is magnificent; and the front one of the finest I ever saw. But the sides being unplaistered give it altogether an incongruous appearance— It is said to have cost 350,000 silver Roubles, and is yet unfinished— I went afterwards with Mr: Harris to see the new Exchange, which is likewise unfinished. Mr: Thomond is the Architect of this building, which is remarkable principally for its simplicity— Mr: Harris also pass’d the Evening at my house— I was in my writing-chamber— Finished reading Smith’s Theory of Moral Sentiments.

22. Captain Groves, Captain Haskell, and Mr: Barthe came this morning to inform me that they expected to sail for the United States to-morrow. The Chevalier Brancia likewise paid me a long visit. I walked before and after dinner— As I was going out after dinner I met Mr: Harris, who told me that he had just heard of a decision of Baron Campenhausen which had given him much pain. It seems a quantity of sugars brought by American vessels, have been entered at the Custom-house of Archangel as raw sugars— They have been seized on the ground that they were really refined sugars, crushed to powder, and falsely entered as raw, to evade the higher duties of impost levied upon refined sugars— This was the business upon which Mr: Andrews was deputed— They affirm that these are really raw Havannah sugars, which have in fact a strong resemblance to refined sugars and liable to be mistaken for them— Mr: Harris on the arrival of Mr: Andrews sent a Note to Baron Campenhausen to this effect and complaining in strong terms of the revisor, by whom the seizure was made— Samples of the sugars had been sent to Baron Campenhausen for his inspection, upon examination of which he pronounced them to be refined sugars reduced to powder; and he wrote to Mr: Harris requesting him to come and inspect the sugars himself— Harris still persisted that they were raw sugars, and proposed to Baron Campenhausen to have the samples submitted to the inspection of two Merchants and a refiner; which the Baron has accordingly done— The two merchants were Mr: P. Severin, and Mr: B. Cramer; and Harris had just learnt that they too have pronounced the sugars to have been refined and then powdered— It has placed him in an aukward situation after the part that he has taken in the business; and I have narrowly escaped getting into one myself— As the case now stands its appearance is not favourable to Mr: Andrews or his constituents— But Harris still insists that the decision concerning the sugars is erroneous and absurd— His principal reason however now is, the respectability of the merchants who made the shipments— One of the samples he says came in a vessel of Mr: Gray’s—The Rebecca— The Ladies went this Evening to the Play— I spent it in reading Mallet’s History of the Hanseatic league, lent me by Mr: Wiggers.

23— Mr: Harris called upon me this Morning— He had just been paying a visit to Monsieur de Gourieff the Minister of the Finances who is now also Minister of Commerce— Mr: Gourieff assured him that the greatest restrictions upon trade now existing would soon be removed— On coming out from him he received also a Note from Baron Campenhausen in answer to the last that he had sent him concerning the sugars seized at Archangel— This Note announced the unanimous decision of the examiners, that the sugars were refined; charged the importers with an intention of paying duties far less than the real article would have paid; and vindicated the conduct of the Revisor, in terms of the highest approbation. Mr: Harris was much embarrassed what to do and asked my advice— I advised him to reply by a full explanation of the difference between the Havannah and refined sugars; by a full exposure of the Circumstances tending to shew that these could not have been refined; and then to conclude by observing that after having done every thing in his power and conformably to his duty to protect the rights and interests of his Countrymen, he should as became him leave the subject to whatever decision this Government thought proper to make concerning it— He called again in the Evening, and told me that he had been with Mr: Andrews to Baron Campenhausen, and had given him every possible explanation— Had assured him that these goods were imported in this state from the Havannah— That a large parcel of them had been sold at Archangel for 24. Roubles per Poud; while the price of refined sugars was at 60— That the duty levied upon refined sugars, if now required upon this, would be sufficient to produce to him a loss of fifty Cent upon his voyage—and that the rest was of the same kind— Harris says that Campenhausen appeared much surprized, at this explanation, and professed that he would do every thing possible to secure justice eventually to the importers. I pass’d the day at home and read Massillon’s Panegyric upon Saint Agnes— The first in his volume of panegyrics— This Lady is said to have lived at the beginning of the fourth century, and to have died a martyr. Massillon says very little of her History— He speaks of her beauty; her chastity; her refusal of many high offers of marriage; and her suffering persecution and death, in general terms.— It seems there are panegyrics of this same Saint extant; by the most celebrated fathers.— I was reading this Evening the character of Joseph in Robinson, when Mr: Harris and Mr: J. S. Smith came in— Soon after a very large packet was brought me, with a note from Count Romanzoff, and containing the dispatches, I have for sometime been expecting— There were several letters and duplicates from the Secretary of State, one from the Secretary of the Treasury enclosing a Bill of exchange from Mr: Daschkoff, drawn upon Mr: Colombi, for 4000 guilders, at the rate of exchange here, when the bill will become payable; which I am directed to receive— A letter from Mr: Plumer; and Newspapers from April, untill June 18th.— I asked Mr: Harris what were the days of grace allowed upon a bill by the custom here—he says ten days— But that they are seldom taken; the merchants usually paying the bill at the day.

24. I went this morning to Mr: Colombi’s house to present Mr: Daschkoff’s bill of Exchange; but he had not returned from his house in the Country, where he usually spends the Sunday— With the Ladies, and Mr: W. S. Smith, I went to see the Palace and Gardens at Peterhoff, 26 versts from the City, and 29 from our house in the City.— We went in a Coach, with our own four horses, and two others— Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Jones, met us there— They went in a chariot and four— We were precisely two hours in going from our own house to the gate of the Palace at Peterhoff— The distance is between 19 and 20 miles, which we went without stopping once, either to rest or water the horses— Such is the common practice here; and their small, mean-looking horses appear not to suffer from it at-all— We were upwards of three hours in going over the Palace, its various out-houses which are seven or eight, and the Gardens.— The Palace is an image of magnificence in a late, almost the last stage of decay— . . .d hangings of rich damask— Once gilded wainscoting and doors; carved work of great cost, but extinguished fashions, Chinese lackering, and pictures perished upon the canvas, from the damps of uninhabited apartments, constitute the whole furniture of the buildings— One of the outbuildings, is appropriated for baths; and there are all the conveniences for common water baths, shower baths and Russian steam-baths. We were told they were sometimes used by Maria Fedorowna; that is by the Empress Mother. Another is the Empress Elizabeth’s kitchen; for this Sovereign of the Empire prided herself upon her skill in Cookery, and was used to prepare dinners for select parties in this building— The kitchen is much upon the Rumford plan— Catherine the second
who had other tastes besides those of Cookery, had in these buildings also a hermitage where a table for twelve persons descends and ascends by machinery so that it may be served, without the presence of any servants in the apartment with the Company— From this chamber there is a balcony in front, just before a large fish pond; full of carp. They come upon the summons of a Bell, rung by one of the Servants, and feed upon the crumbs of brown bread thrown to them upon the water— And there is a balcony in the rear, facing the gulph of Finland, and from which there is a full view of Cronstadt— But the principal curiosities of the place are the water-works; all of which were set to playing for us to see— There are a great variety of pipes and fountains; some in the form of gilded statues, others of Animals and fish— Some of Urns—some of rolling sheets and some even of plants and trees—the waters are carried to the top of some of the buildings, made to spout from the summit of their domes, and roll down, streaming from their roofs.— The meanest of all the contrivances is a fountain, with three leaden ducks pursued by a dog, which are movable, and made to imitate the barking of the dog and the quack of the ducks— The imitation besides its being ridiculous is very bad— We had taken a cold collation with us, and they lent us a room in one of the external buildings connected with the palace, where we took it— Once a year, in the summer Season the Emperor usually gives a great Ball at this place, to which the public in general are admitted— The gardens are all illuminated and the water-works all played by the light of the illuminations. On these occasions the Foreign Ministers are all accommodated with lodgings at these buildings— But this year the usual entertainment, from motives of economy has been omitted— We quitted Peterhoff at half past 5. O’Clock in the afternoon, and reached home precisely a quarter before eight— We stop’d about ten minutes at the Garden of the Grand Chamberlain Narishkin, to look at a white marble statue, representing the Rape of Proserpine, for which he is said to have given ten thousand roubles, and which is very well executed— There are on the road to Peterhoff a great number of Country seats, inhabited during Summer, by the nobility and the principal merchants— Strelna, the Summer-Residence of the Czarowitz Constantine is of the number— And at the 15th: Werst there is a monastery founded by one of the Count Zuboff’s— We dined about 8 in the Evening immediately after we got home— Mr: Smith and Mr: Jones came home and dined with us.

25. Before Breakfast this morning I had a visit from a messenger of the Minister of Police, with two sailors who have been taken up at Cronstadt, and who give themselves out as Americans— But they have no protections and belong to no American vessel there— And upon examination I found that one of them was by his own story not an American Citizen, and the other though pretending to have been born at Long-Island, spoke English with the accent of a German— They pretended to have been taken by a British Frigate coming from Tonningen to Petersburg in the Brig Hawk from Boston, and after being kept three weeks to have been set on shore upon a Russian Island near Hoogland; from which they found their way in a Transport to Cronstadt. I sent the Gentlemen with them to Mr: Harris. Mr: Andrews and Mr: Plumer called upon me after breakfast; much concerned about the fate of their Havannah Sugars—which they say the College of Commerce as well as Mr: Severin and Mr: Cramer, and the Sugar-refiner have pronounced to be refined sugars afterwards powdered— I afterwards called upon Mr: Harris, to speak on the subject with him— The two Sailors he says are English Seamen, who have made their escape from some British Man of War— As to the sugars he says Mr: Meyer has seen them, and pronounces them with the most undoubting certainty, white Havanna Sugars and not refined— Mr: Harris shewed me some letters which he is writing to the Secretaries of State and of the Treasury; and consulted me again upon his answer to Baron Campenhausen— As he is much hurt, and not without reason at the Baron’s letter to him, I recommended again to him coolness, and the suppression of all resentment, at least untill the suspicions too much countenanced by the appearances hitherto shall effectually be removed— I then went to Mr: Colombi’s, and presented Mr: Daschkoff’s bill; which Mr: Colombi accepted; and said he should pay at the sixtieth day, without taking any days of grace.— Baron de Mülinen the Secretary of the Wirtemberg legation spent part of the Evening with us.

26. Morning visits from Mr: Montréal and Mr Harris— Mr: Montréal told me of some political intrigues in agitation; and brought me a couple of pamphlets containing information concerning the cultivation of hemp. Mr: Harris says that there happened to be one member of the College of Commerce who understood something of the nature of Havanna sugars, and who pronounced the samples brought from Archangel to be of that description— In consequence of which the report of the College has been suspended, and the appearances begin to be more favourable to the persons interested— As I was little acquainted with the different sorts of sugar myself, and the various processes of its refinement I have been making some enquiries concerning it, and consulted
Jaubert’s Dictionnaire des Arts et Métiers— I was thus engaged untill dinner time, and walked immediately after dinner. The days are already so short, and are so rapidly growing shorter that after the close of this month I shall be obliged to take all my exercise in the morning— Spent the Evening in writing, and in reading the newspapers lent me by the French Ambassador. I have made it a practice for several years to read the Bible through in the course of every year— I usually devote to this reading the first hour after I rise every morning— As including the Apocrypha it contains about 1400 chapters, and as I meet with occasional interruptions, when this reading is for single days, and sometimes for weeks; or even months suspended, my rule is to read five chapters each morning, which leaves an allowance for about one fourth of the time for such interruptions— Extraordinary pressure of business, seldom interrupts more than one day’s reading at a time— Sickness has frequently occasioned longer suspensions— And travelling still more and longer— During the present year, having lost very few days, I have finished the perusal earlier than usual— I closed the book yesterday— As I do not wish to suspend the habit of allowing regularly this time to this purpose, I have this morning commenced it anew— And for the sake of endeavouring to understand the Book better, as well as of giving some variety to the study, I have begun this time, with Ostervald’s french Translation; which has the advantage of a few short reflections upon each chapter.— I ought perhaps to be ashamed at having read this Book through, so many times, and at possessing its contents so little as I do— The regular and methodical manner of reading is not without defects— The division, by a given number of chapters is arbitrary and artificial— The appropriation of a certain hour inevitably devotes times when occasionally the attention is absorbed by objects, passions, interests, feelings, which the affairs of life bring up as it runs, and when the mind cannot command its application— The Bible is in many of its parts, as Saint Peter says of his brother Paul’s Epistles, hard to be understood— It presents difficulties of various kinds— The help of Commentators I have scarcely ever had at hand, and if I had, could not use, without devoting several hours of every day, instead of one to this object— It has long been one of the numerous Resolutions, which I take, and do not fulfill, to undertake this at some indefinite time; but I am always making to myself excuses for postponing it to some future time— Imperfect as my method is, I regret none of the time thus bestowed— At every perusal, I do add something to my knowledge of the Scriptures—something to my veneration of them, and I would hope, something to the improvement, which ought to result from this occupation, and which is the great motive to it— I received notice from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies, Narishkin, that there would be a Court held to-morrow, on the anniversary of the Emperor’s Coronation, and a Te Deum on occasion of the late victory over the Turks.

27. At Noon I attended, with Mr: W. S. Smith at the Palace, conformably to the official notice— I had been desired to attend earlier than usual, as the notice was both for a Court, and a Te Deum— We went therefore precisely at twelve, the hour appointed; but found there was no Court, to be held, and the Te Deum did not commence untill near two— There was a Mass performed, immediately before the Te Deum, at which the Corps Diplomatique did not attend— We were introduced just as the Te Deum commenced— The Imperial family were there as usual excepting the Grand Duchess Ann— Mr: Rosenzweig the Chargé des Affaires from Saxony told me that General Watzdorf, the new Minister from his Court arrived last Evening. I had some Conversation with the French Ambassador, from which I understand that he has received new instructions relative to the Commerce in what are called colonial Articles— I thanked him for the loan of the Moniteur’s, and for the return of the English Papers which he had lent me— I mentioned to him that I had observed with pleasure the attendance of General Armstrong at Court, on the Emperor Napoleon’s birth-day; considering it as an indication that our relations were becoming again more favourable in their aspect there— He said he had again received assurances that the dispositions of his Government were extremely friendly towards the United States— I said then that they should make a clear and a strong distinction between the English & the Americans— That he said in relation to Commerce was very difficult— I assured him, that the only difficulty was in the inclination— That if this existed, nothing was more easy; as was completely proved in this Country; where either the Consul or myself could and did easily discriminate between those who pretended to be Americans, and the English who on false pretences gave themselves out as such— I mentioned to him the vessels, which had been detected as coming with false papers by Mr: Harris, and consequently seized and confiscated by this Government; and also the persons whom I had detected myself— I told him that only two days ago the Minister of Police had sent me two Sailors, who
pretended to be Americans, but whom upon five minutes conversation I found not to be such, and whom therefore I sent back to him— I enumerated the particulars by which we were enabled to make this discrimination— The different pronuntiation of the language— The personal acquaintance we have with many of the merchants who trade here— And the secret marks of the Papers— If France was making War against the English, there was no real difficulty in distinguishing between them and the Americans; but if she was making War against certain Articles of Merchandize, to be sure, discrimination would be of no Avail— He told me, that to be candid, there was a pretty strong sentiment against the colonial trade at Paris, because they considered it as all English— For, says he—you, for instance raise no sugar— I told him that he was much mistaken— That a great deal of sugar was raised in the United States; and particularly in the Country ceded to us by France—Louisiana— But Cotton—Indigo— We were perhaps the greatest raisers of these Articles in the world, they were among our most valuable staple Articles— Besides, there were the Spanish Islands—South America—these were not English—and the Emperor Napoleon could not consider them as such; for he had more than once officially declared his friendliness to them, and his willingness for their Independence— With regard to that he said he could not give an opinion— But as to the Certificates of Origin said to be given by French Consuls in America, he was assured that they must be false, as the Consuls no longer gave any such certificates— I assured him in the most earnest terms that this was a mistake— That to my certain knowledge vessels which had sailed from the United States, as late as the month of June, had brought genuine Certificates of Origin from the French Consuls— I then added that if these were the Sentiments prevailing still with the French Government, I could not but lament it— That as long as they prevailed, however strong the friendly dispositions towards the United States might be said to be, the course of policy pursued must be injurious to them in the highest degree— You will do us, said I, immense injury— You will oppress the Continent of Europe, and yourselves with it; but take my word for it, and I pray you three years hence to remember what I say, you will do England more good than harm; you will not cut off her Communication with the Continent; you will not essentially distress her Commerce; but you will lay the world under the most grievous contributions, for her benefit and advantage— But said he; there is a prodigious accumulation of colonial articles and of her manufactures on her hands which she cannot dispose of; her Bank paper money is depretiating. Her merchants and great manufacturers are becoming bankrupts; the course of exchange is draining her of metallic specie; and therefore perseverance in this system must eventually compel her to come to terms of Peace— Why then said I, did she not snatch at the offer which you have just made her, of giving up the whole system?— I see nothing like a symptom of her giving up even her orders of Council— No! she wishes you to adhere to your system; because she knows and feels that it turns to her advantage— You speak of the accumulation of colonial articles in her warehouses; and what is the accumulation of your wines and brandies, and what was the accumulation of grain upon your hands?— It has induced you to grant licences for vessels to go from any where to England, and to bring back what they please; only upon the condition that they export an equal quantity or value of your productions from France— He said he was informed that the importations were restricted to certain specific articles, and did not include colonial articles generally— I told him that my information was very different, and it was a notorious fact that immediately on the understanding being had that this trade by licences was to be allowed, the price of colonial Articles in London had immediately risen ten or twelve per Cent— The Chevalier Brancia told me that he found upon enquiry my information respecting the proposition made in the Imperial-Council for securing the election of Prince George of Oldenburg as the successor to the throne of Sweden, by the restoration of Finland, was correct; and he also told me that the late king of Sweden had come to the frontiers of this Country, and written to the Emperor, requesting permission to Embark from his dominions, and go to England— That the Emperor had sent his aid de Camp Count Ozarowsky to him, but with what answer, was not known— I walked immediately after dinner— In the Evening there was the most general illumination that there has been since our arrival here— This is the third in the space of three weeks.

28. Mr: Meyer called upon me this morning and brought an explanatory statement of the new Commission charges, which have given occasion to complaints among the Americans— He mentioned at the same time the arrival at Cronstadt of Mr: Gray’s ship American Hero, Captain Leech; and his desire to transact Mr: Gray’s business— Having now funds of that Gentleman in his hands— Mr: Harris soon after
called upon me, and mentioned the arrival of the same ship, with a very valuable Cargo of Cotton, intimating the same wish with Mr: Meyer’s, though not quite so explicit in expressing it— He also came and dined with us, and renewed the mention of this arrival in the Evening— Asking me, whether she would be under the direction of young Mr: Gray— I did not know— Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray returned last Evening from their tour to Moscow, and this Evening dined with us; as did Mr: J. S. Smith, and Mr Jones— In the Evening we had music and a game of Chess.

29. I had a visit this morning from Mr: Montreal— Captain Leach of Mr: Gray’s ship, went to Mr: F. C. Gray with Mr: Glukoff, who solicited and obtained of him, the transaction of the business of this ship— I employed the morning with various occupations; but accomplished no writing, except to keep up with the current of time in my journal— I walked morning and Evening—read some chapters in Mallet’s book upon the Hanseatic league, and finished Monsieur Cordier de Launay’s Treatise upon the two different kinds of the beautiful; a work in which some extravagance is blended with much ingenuity— There is certainly great foundation for his theory of two kinds of the beautiful. His circumspheric theory is a chimaera— He might have taken Homer’s Odyssey, for his model of the composite beautiful, with almost as much reason as the Paradise Lost.— And he could no more have reduced Ariosto to his beautiful of imitation, than the Revelation of St: John— The Ladies went this Evening to the play.

30. I renewed again the intention of employing a due proportion of this day, to the occupations and meditations, suitable for it. But received in the forenoon a note from Mr: Navarro, mentioning his intention to dispatch a Courier early on Wednesday morning, who was going to Brazil, and would pass through London, upon his way— He offered to take any packet for me which I should chuse to send by him, and I concluded to write to the Secretary of State— It engaged me untill nearly the hour of dinner— Mr: Gray dined with us; Mr: Everett was gone to the hunt; and Mr: Smith dined at Mr: Krehmer’s— In the Evening I read Massillon’s Panegyric, upon St: Francis of Paule— This was one of the ascetic Saints who lived in the fifteenth Century— A man of obscure birth and unlettered education, who acquired the reputation of sanctity by his austerities, and self-chastisements— The bishop gives no regular biographical account of him, but alludes to some of the incidents of his life, as to Events well known— He was the founder of the order of minims, a name which he gave to his monks to denote their great humility— He was also it seems a performer of miracles; upon which there is a remarkable passage in this Panegyric— The learned prelate between his philosophical light and his religious prejudices; between the glory of his Saint and the ridicule of his superstitious legends appears embarrassed what to say, and finally says what he ought not. He plainly shews that he holds all these pretended miracles as spurious, and yet he censures the age for not believing them.— In another passage, with terms almost irreverent he charges God almighty with avenging his justice by multiplying crimes upon Earth; and calls for an exterminating angel to destroy that usurping Jeroboam, William 3— This discourse is one of those which teem with figurative scriptural allusions; many of which were ingenious; and some far fetched and quaint— Its morality appears to me very defective— I also read the remainder of Joseph’s character in Robinson, which I had left unfinished last Sunday, and also the character of Job.— This author has one peculiarity which I think creditable to him— He censures with becoming severity those parts of the conduct of the patriarchs which appear to deserve censure— He supposes Job to have been anterior to the time of Moses.

Day. Very little different from the last months— My life is now sufficiently regular; but occupied with objects not sufficiently important. The Evenings are growing very long, and with the weakness of my eyes, I shall soon again be obliged to lose a great part of them.
